properties.Description: Red Hill Gulch Overflow Channel East - an in-town option to control surface flows before they impact residential structures, significant impacts on Town Park features.
Red Hill Gulch Overflow Channel West - Acquisition of land outside of Town limits captures surface flows without impacting park lands, but costs increase for land and drop structures.

Red Hill Gulch Cut-Off Channel - An upstream cut off outside of Town limits reduces risk to Town public and private land, but requires detailed design and coordination with County, irrigation companies, and private residents.
Steamboat Drainage Culvert Replacement - an overdeveloped natural drainageway improvement will require extensive private property acquisition and impact multiple historic resources.

Steamboat Drainage Interceptors - to maximize capacity of existing Steamboat stone culverts, surface flows are intercepted and routed away from the undersized natural drainageway to be conveyed in the gutter and streets.
Third Avenue Inlets and Storm Drain - an expensive but effective storm sewer system captures and conveys water away from private property and out of public ROW.
Lower Third Avenue Inlet - Rock excavation and storm sewer cost can be reduced if only lower section of 3rd Avenue storm sewer is improved.
Third Avenue Drainage Interceptors - an improvement to surface conveyance moves the flood risk away from private structures and into public ROW but only reduces the damages from large storm events.
Eastern Lyons Second Avenue Gutter Interceptor - another hillside drainage solution that improves street capacity to move storm water runoff south in public ROW and away from private property.
Eastern Lyons Second Avenue Inlets and Storm Sewer - to reduce flood risk more than gutter improvements a system of storm sewer inlets and pipes can be installed.
Lyons Valley South Ditch Improvements - surface runoff drains through the subdivision to the river, but a diversion ditch on the southern perimeter of the development can reduce risk.

Lyons Valley McConnel Drive Culvert - nuisance and storm flows from impervious surfaces occupy and overwhelm the west flow line, inlets and storm sewer can improve conveyance and reduce surface flood risks.
Ewald Avenue Corona Hill Diversion Ditch - intercepting hillside runoff above the private property requires costly open space acquisition and challenging hydraulics moving water downhill.
Ewald Avenue Corona Hill Street Inlets - an alternative to uphill diversion is in-street capture and conveyance to a pond or outlet to the river.

2nd Avenue Kelling Drive Improvements - private property drainage is complicated by landscaping and undefined flow paths and may require assistance coordinating individual efforts to ensure compliance with Town criteria and drainage law.

Stone Canyon Outfall Improvements - larger upstream culverts discharge into smaller downstream conveyance elements constrained by roads and topography, an expensive and complicated upsizing would reduce flood risk in this area.
